title: Bernie Sanders Returns to Trail With Fresh Endorsements—and Challenges
text:
Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D., N.Y.), left, and Bernie Sanders in New York City at Mr. Sanders’s first major campaign rally since he suffered a heart attack earlier this month.

LONG ISLAND CITY, N.Y.— Bernie Sanders is back on the campaign trail and looking to project confidence.

Standing in front of what his campaign said was nearly 26,000 people here, Sen. Sanders (I., Vt.) said he was “more than ready to assume the office of president of United States” following a heart attack Oct. 1.

Mr. Sanders and his campaign are hoping for a revival to tick up his sluggish poll numbers—which show a notable lack of support among older voters—following two weeks off the campaign trail that raised questions about the future of his bid. Aides and allies of Mr. Sanders said Saturday’s event here, with the Queensboro Bridge in the background, is a sign of positive things to come.

The rally capped off a strong week back for Mr. Sanders, whose first public appearance was the debate Tuesday. Then fundraising numbers came out showing he had millions more dollars than his opponents. He also secured two major endorsements with progressive Democratic social-media stars New York Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Minnesota Rep. Ilhan Omar. Ms. Ocasio-Cortez introduced Mr. Sanders Saturday.

“Overcoming adversity is built into the DNA of Bernie’s campaign. We thrive in it,” said Mike Casca, a spokesman for Mr. Sanders. (Mr. Sanders’s long-shot bid against former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton in 2016 turned into a legitimate fight for the Democratic Party nomination.)

The Sanders campaign said nearly 26,000 people attended the rally on Saturday. Photo: Natalie Keyssar for The Wall Street Journal

At 78, Mr. Sanders is the oldest candidate in the field, but supporters said his age was an asset because it meant wisdom of life experience.

SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS Do you think Bernie Sanders can improve his support among older voters? Why or why not? Join the conversation below.

“Bernie has shown a very quick rebound. He still has the same really aggressive, mental vitality that a lot of other candidates in the race haven’t shown,” said Katelin Penner, 19, a student at Wesleyan University, who coleads her university’s group of Sanders supporters.

“The only heart attack we should be talking about, is the one Wall Street is going to have when Bernie Sanders is president,” said filmmaker Michael Moore, who spoke at the rally and endorsed Mr. Sanders Saturday.

But not everyone was as confident Mr. Sanders would win.

Mr. Sanders has remained stagnant in polls. Meanwhile, fellow progressive Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren has risen, closing the gap with former Vice President Joe Biden, who has long been the front-runner.

Pat Maren, a 26-year-old financial analyst living in New York City, said he didn’t see how Mr. Sanders would be able to make a comeback, even if his influence over the Democratic Party has been a victory on its own.

“You have the gang here that are endorsing him, but that’s not exactly broadening his base,” said Mr. Maren. “I think he’s capped.”

Attendees at Bernie Sanders’s campaign rally on Saturday. Photo: Natalie Keyssar for The Wall Street Journal

It will be difficult for the Vermont senator to move to the top of the crowded field if he doesn’t make inroads with older voters who are more likely to participate in primaries.

A Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll from September, before Mr. Sanders’s heart attack, found Mr. Sanders had the support of 27% of Democratic voters under age 50, but just 3% of voters over 50.

Meanwhile, Ms. Warren drew a quarter of voters from each age group. Mr. Biden had support from 17% of those surveyed under 50 and 42% of Democratic primary voters over.

When voters’ second choices were added into the poll, Mr. Sanders didn’t do much better with older voters. September’s poll followed trends in data consistent with polling done for The Wall Street Journal and NBC News throughout 2019.

Republican pollster Bill McInturff, who conducted this survey with the Democratic pollsters, said the data on older voters was devastating to Mr. Sanders and would be difficult to change because his name identification is already high.

“I believe that there’s nothing in these current set of numbers that makes it look like he could be nominated by the Democratic Party,” Mr. McInturff said. “But there’s always an asterisk, which is weird stuff happens in Democratic primaries” and Mr. Sanders has enough money and passionate supporters to remain in the race in case of an upset.

Mr. Sanders has nearly $34 million on hand, about $8 million ahead of Ms. Warren’s nearly $26 million. He is $25 million ahead of Mr. Biden, who has just about $9 million on hand. He also has attracted over a million grass-roots donors.

Rep. Ro Khanna (D., Calif.), who is a co-chair of Mr. Sanders’s campaign, said Mr. Sanders simply needed to tell older, working class voters—many of whom are currently supporting Mr. Biden—that his economic record and policies are better for them.

“He needs to share that Medicare for All plan that he’s proposing is going to give seniors long-term care, is going to give them dental and vision, is really going to be something that is good for seniors,” Mr. Khanna said.

Some of Mr. Sanders’s supporters say he is galvanizing a whole new section of the Democratic Party electorate. Photo: Natalie Keyssar for The Wall Street Journal

But some of Mr. Sanders’s supporters said he didn’t need to focus on turning out traditional Democratic primary voters who weren’t supporting him because he, with the help of allies of color like Ms. Ocasio-Cortez and Ms. Omar, was engaging a whole new section of the electorate.

“It’s about mobilizing a sector of voters who have not traditionally been a part of the movement,” said Honda Wang, 27, a Democratic Socialists of America member who works in sales and lives in Brooklyn.

—Aaron Zitner contributed to this article.

Write to Eliza Collins at eliza.collins@wsj.com.
description: Sen. Bernie Sanders returned to the campaign trail Saturday with high-profile endorsements following a heart attack suffered earlier this month.
